title: Chain complex
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, a chain complex is an <a href="algebraic%20structure">algebraic structure</a> that consists of a sequence of <a href="abelian%20group">abelian group</a>s (or <a href="module%20%28mathematics%29">modules</a>) and a sequence of <a href="group%20homomorphism">homomorphisms</a> between consecutive groups such that the <a href="image%20%28mathematics%29">image</a> of each homomorphism is included in the <a href="kernel%20%28algebra%29%23Group%20homomorphisms">kernel</a> of the next. Associated to a chain complex is its <a href="Homology%20%28mathematics%29">homology</a>, which describes how the images are included in the kernels.
A cochain complex is similar to a chain complex, except that its homomorphisms are in the opposite direction. The homology of a cochain complex is called its <a href="cohomology">cohomology</a>.
In <a href="algebraic%20topology">algebraic topology</a>, the singular chain complex of a <a href="topological%20space">topological space</a> X is constructed using <a href="continuous%20function%23continuous%20functions%20between%20topological%20spaces">continuous maps</a> from a <a href="simplex">simplex</a> to X, and the homomorphisms of the chain complex capture how these maps restrict to the boundary of the simplex. The homology of this chain complex is called the <a href="singular%20homology">singular homology</a> of X, and is a commonly used <a href="topological%20invariant">invariant</a> of a topological space.
Chain complexes are studied in <a href="homological%20algebra">homological algebra</a>, but are used in several areas of mathematics, including <a href="abstract%20algebra">abstract algebra</a>, <a href="Galois%20theory">Galois theory</a>, <a href="differential%20geometry">differential geometry</a> and <a href="algebraic%20geometry">algebraic geometry</a>. They can be defined more generally in <a href="abelian%20categories">abelian categories</a>.
Definitions.
A chain complex formula_1 is a sequence of abelian groups or modules ..., "A"0, "A"1, "A"2, "A"3, "A"4, ... connected by homomorphisms (called boundary operators or differentials) , such that the composition of any two consecutive maps is the zero map. Explicitly, the differentials satisfy , or with indices suppressed, . The complex may be written out as follows.
The cochain complex formula_3 is the <a href="dual%20%28category%20theory%29">dual</a> notion to a chain complex. It consists of a sequence of abelian groups or modules ..., "A"0, "A"1, "A"2, "A"3, "A"4, ... connected by homomorphisms satisfying . The cochain complex may be written out in a similar fashion to the chain complex.
The index "n" in either "A""n" or "A""n" is referred to as the degree (or dimension). The difference between chain and cochain complexes is that, in chain complexes, the differentials decrease dimension, whereas in cochain complexes they increase dimension. All the concepts and definitions for chain complexes apply to cochain complexes, except that they will follow this different convention for dimension, and often terms will be given the <a href="prefix">prefix</a> "co-". In this article, definitions will be given for chain complexes when the distinction is not required.
A bounded chain complex is one in which <a href="almost%20all%23cardinality">almost all</a> the "A""n" are 0; that is, a finite complex extended to the left and right by 0. An example is the chain complex defining the <a href="simplicial%20homology">simplicial homology</a> of a finite <a href="simplicial%20complex">simplicial complex</a>. A chain complex is bounded above if all modules above some fixed degree "N" are 0, and is bounded below if all modules below some fixed degree are 0. Clearly, a complex is bounded both above and below if and only if the complex is bounded.
The elements of the individual groups of a (co)chain complex are called (co)chains. The elements in the kernel of "d" are called (co)cycles (or closed elements), and the elements in the image of "d" are called (co)boundaries (or exact elements). Right from the definition of the differential, all boundaries are cycles. The "n"-th (co)homology group "H""n" ("H""n") is the group of (co)cycles <a href="modulo%20%28jargon%29%23structures">modulo</a> (co)boundaries in degree "n", that is,
Exact sequences.
An exact sequence (or exact complex) is a chain complex whose homology groups are all zero. This means all closed elements in the complex are exact. Chain maps.
A chain map "f" between two chain complexes formula_7 and formula_8 is a sequence formula_9 of homomorphisms formula_10 for each "n" that commutes with the boundary operators on the two chain complexes, so formula_11. A chain map sends cycles to cycles and boundaries to boundaries, and thus induces a map on homology formula_12.
A continuous map "f" between topological spaces "X" and "Y" induces a chain map between the singular chain complexes of "X" and "Y", and hence induces a map "f"* between the singular homology of "X" and "Y" as well. When "X" and "Y" are both equal to the <a href="n-sphere">"n"-sphere</a>, the map induced on homology defines the <a href="Degree%20of%20a%20continuous%20mapping%23From%20Sn%20to%20Sn">degree</a> of the map "f".
The concept of chain map reduces to the one of boundary through the construction of the <a href="Mapping%20cone%20%28homological%20algebra%29">cone</a> of a chain map.
Chain homotopy.
A chain homotopy offers a way to relate two chain maps that induce the same map on homology groups, even though the maps may be different. Given two chain complexes "A" and "B", and two chain maps , a chain homotopy is a sequence of homomorphisms such that . The map "hd""A" + "d""B""h" is easily verified to induce the zero map on homology, for any "h". It immediately follows that "f" and "g" induce the same map on homology. One says "f" and "g" are chain homotopic (or simply homotopic), and this property defines an <a href="equivalence%20relation">equivalence relation</a> between chain maps.
Let "X" and "Y" be topological spaces. In the case of singular homology, a <a href="homotopy">homotopy</a> between continuous maps induces a chain homotopy between the chain maps corresponding to "f" and "g". This shows that two homotopic maps induce the same map on singular homology. The name "chain homotopy" is motivated by this example.
Examples.
Singular homology.
Let "X" be a topological space. Define "C""n"("X") for <a href="Natural%20number">natural</a> "n" to be the <a href="free%20abelian%20group">free abelian group</a> formally generated by <a href="singular%20homology">singular n-simplices</a> in "X", and define the boundary map formula_13 to be

It can be shown that ∂2 = 0, so formula_15 is a chain complex; the singular homology formula_16 is the homology of this complex.
Singular homology is a useful invariant of topological spaces up to <a href="homotopy%23homotopy%20equivalence">homotopy equivalence</a>. The degree zero homology group is a free abelian group on the <a href="connected%20space%23Path%20connectedness">path-components</a> of "X".
de Rham cohomology.
The <a href="differential%20form">differential "k"-forms</a> on any <a href="smooth%20manifold">smooth manifold</a> "M" form a <a href="real%20number">real</a> <a href="vector%20space">vector space</a> called Ω"k"("M") under addition. 
The <a href="exterior%20derivative">exterior derivative</a> "d" maps Ω"k"("M") to Ω"k"+1("M"), and "d" = 0 follows essentially from <a href="symmetry%20of%20second%20derivatives">symmetry of second derivatives</a>, so the vector spaces of "k"-forms along with the exterior derivative are a cochain complex.
The cohomology of this complex is called the de Rham cohomology of "X". The homology group in dimension zero is isomorphic to the vector space of <a href="locally%20constant%20function">locally constant function</a>s from "M" to R. Thus for a compact manifold, this is the real vector space whose dimension is the number of connected components of "M".
<a href="smoothness%23smooth%20functions%20between%20manifolds">Smooth maps</a> between manifolds induce chain maps, and smooth homotopies between maps induce chain homotopies.
